{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The history of the '''Bahá'í Faith (Вера Бахаи) in Russia''' began soon after the founding in 1844 of the [[Bábism|Bábí religion]], viewed by Bahá'ís as the direct predecessor of the [[Bahá'í Faith]], with [[Russia]]n diplomats to [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar Persia]] observing, reacting to, and sending updates about the Bábís.[http://bahai-studies.ca/journal/files/jbs/5.3%20Hassall.pdf "Notes on the Bábí and Bahá'í Religions in Russia and its Territories"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706164853/http://bahai-studies.ca/journal/files/jbs/5.3%20Hassall.pdf |date=July 6, 2011 }}, by Graham Hassall, Journal of Bahá'í Studies, 5.3 (Sept.-Dec. 1993) The woman later known as [[Táhirih]], who played a central role in the religion of the [[Báb]], was from an influential clerical family from [[Azerbaijan]], which was then [[History of Azerbaijan#Transition from Iranian rule to Russian rule|ruled by Russia]].{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Baha'i Faith History in Azerbaijan |work= |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Azerbaijan |url=http://www.bahai.az/lib/articles/histofaz/history_en.shtml |doi= |accessdate=2008-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219032306/http://www.bahai.az/lib/articles/histofaz/history_en.shtml |archivedate=2012-02-19 }} Russian diplomats later protected [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the founder of the Bahá'í Faith, before and after his exile from Persia.{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan |title = Russia | work = Draft for "A Short Encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith" | publisher = Bahá'í Library Online | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_russia | accessdate = 2008-04-14}} Around 1884, the religion began to spread into the [[Russian Empire]],{{cite web|author=Local Spiritual Assembly of Kyiv |title=Statement on the history of the Bahá'í Faith in Soviet Union |work=Official Website of the Bahá'ís of Kyiv |date=August 2007 |url=http://bahai.kiev.ua/history9.html |accessdate=2010-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715093037/http://bahai.kiev.ua/history9.html |archivedate=July 15, 2010 }} where the Bahá'í community in [[Ashgabat]] built the first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]], elected one of the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly|local administrative institutions]] and became a center of scholarship. The Bahá'í Faith also attracted the attention of several Russian scholars and artists. During the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] period, Russia adopted the [[Religion in the Soviet Union#Policy toward religions in practice|Soviet policy of oppression]] of religion, leading the Russian Bahá'í community to abandon its administration and properties in accordance with its principle of obedience to legal government,{{cite book | last = Effendi | first = Shoghi | authorlink = Shoghi Effendi | title = The World Order of Bahá'u'lláh | publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust, 1991 first pocket-size edition | date = 1936-03-11 | location = Haifa, Palestine |pages = 64–67 | url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/wob-34.html#pg64| isbn =}} though Bahá'ís across the Soviet Union were nevertheless sent to prisons and camps or abroad.{{cite conference|last=Momen |first=Moojan |title=Turkmenistan |booktitle=draft of "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" |publisher=Bahá'í Library Online |year=1994 |url=http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/turkmnst.htm |accessdate=2008-05-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509200356/http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/turkmnst.htm |archivedate=2008-05-09 }} Before the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] Bahá'ís in several cities were able to gather and organize as [[Perestroyka]] spread from Moscow through many Soviet republics. The Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the Russian Federations was ultimately formed in 1995.http://bahai-library.com/hassall_nsas_years_formation The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated the number of Bahá'ís in Russia at about 18,990 in 2005.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives |year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 2010-05-03}} == Early period == === Russian Empire === In the beginning of the earliest phase, the religion had strong connections with Azerbaijan during the [[History of Azerbaijan#Russian rule|Russian rule in Azerbaijan]] in the [[Russian Empire]]. Among the most notable facts is a woman of Azerbaijani background who would play a central role in the religion of the [[Báb]], viewed by Bahá´ís as the direct predecessor of the Bahá'í Faith – she would be later named [[Tahirih]], though her story would be in the context of Persia. She was among the [[Letters of the Living]] of the Báb. In 1847, the Russian ambassador to [[Tehran]], Prince [[Dimitri Ivanovich Dolgorukov]], and other diplomats became aware of the claims of the Báb and seeing the fleeing of Bábís across the border requested that the Báb, then imprisoned at [[Maku, Iran|Maku]], be moved elsewhere; he also condemned the massacres of Iranian religionists.{{who|date=November 2016}}{{failed verification|date=November 2016}} Dolgorukov wrote some memoirs later in life but much of it has been shown to be a forgery. But his dispatches show that he was afraid of the movement spreading into the [[Caucasus]].{{citation |last = Momen | year = 2004 | first = Moojan | title = Conspiracies and Forgeries: the attack upon the Baha'i community in Iran | journal = Persian Heritage | volume = 9 | issue = 35 | pages = 27–29|url=http://bahai-library.com/pdf/m/momen_conspiracies_forgeries.pdf|format=pdf}}{{citation |last = Balyuzi |first = H.M. |authorlink = Hasan M. Balyuzi |year = 1973 |title = The Báb: The Herald of the Day of Days |publisher = George Ronald |location = Oxford, UK |isbn = 0-85398-048-9|page=131}} In 1852, after a failed assassination attempt against the Shah of Persia for which the entire Bábí community was blamed, many Bábís, including Bahá'u'lláh, who had no role in the attempt and later severely condemned it, were arrested in a sweep.{{citation |last = Balyuzi|first = H.M. |authorlink = Hasan M. Balyuzi |year = 2000 |title = Bahá'u'lláh, King of Glory |publisher = George Ronald|location = Oxford, UK |isbn = 0-85398-328-3|pages=77–78, 99–100}} When Bahá'u'lláh was jailed by the Shah, his family went to Mírzá Majid Ahi who was married to a sister of Bahá'u'lláh, and was working as the secretary to the Russian Legation in Tehran. Bahá'u'lláh's family asked Mírzá Majid to go to Dolgorukov and ask him to intercede on behalf of Bahá'u'lláh, and Dolgorukov agreed however this assistance was short lived and again the memoirs are known to have many impossible dates in them. In addition, Bahá'u'lláh refused exile in Russia.{{cite book | last =Warburg | first =Margit | editor-last = Hanegraaff | editor-first =W.J. | editor2-last =Kumar | editor2-first = P.P. | title =Citizens of the World; A History and Sociology of the Baha'is from a Globalization Perspective | publisher =Koninklijke Brill NV | series =Numen Book Series Studies in the History of Religions | volume =106| year = 2006 | location = | pages = 34–35, 147 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=tAvXAAAAMAAJ| isbn =978-90-04-14373-9}} In [[God Passes By]], [[Shoghi Effendi]] alludes to the protection the Russian ambassador gave Bahá'u'lláh on different occasions, first after the attempted assassination of [[Naser al-Din Shah Qajar]] and again after the decision to exile Bahá’u’lláh from Iran, expressing his "desire to take Bahá’u’lláh under the protection of his government, and offered to extend every facility for His removal to Russia."{{Cite book|first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink=Shoghi Effendi |year=1944 |page=71 |title=God Passes By |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-020-9 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/GPB/gpb-6.html#pg71 | ref=harv}}{{Cite book|first=Shoghi |last=Effendi |authorlink=Shoghi Effendi |year=1944 |page=106 |title=God Passes By |publisher=Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location=Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn=0-87743-020-9 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/GPB/gpb-6.html#pg106 | ref=harv}} Starting in 1866, while in Adrianople, Bahá'u'lláh started writing a series of letters to world rulers, proclaiming his station as the promised one of all religions.{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= Encyclopædia Iranica |year= 1989|article=Baha'-allah | first = Juan | last = Cole}} His letters also asked them to renounce their material possessions, work together to settle disputes, and endeavour towards the betterment of the world and its peoples. Czar [[Alexander II of Russia]] was among them.
“O Czar of Russia! Incline thine ear unto the voice of God, the King, the Holy, and turn thou unto Paradise, the Spot wherein abideth He Who, among the Concourse on high, beareth the most excellent titles, and Who, in the kingdom of creation, is called by the name of God, the Effulgent, the All-Glorious. Beware that nothing deter thee from setting thy face towards thy Lord, the Compassionate, the Most Merciful.”[http://www.bahai-studies.ca/journal/files/jbs/8.4%20Buck.pdf A Symbolic Profile of the Bahá’í Faith*] by Christopher Buck, ''Journal of Bahá’í Studies'' Vol. 8, number 4 (1998)
In his [[Summons of the Lord of Hosts#Súriy-i-Haykal (Tablet of the Temple)|Súriy-i-Haykal]], Bahá’u’lláh included the Lawh-i-Malik-i-Rús, praising Czar [[Alexander II of Russia]] in these terms: "when this Wronged One was sore-afflicted in prison, the minister of the highly esteemed government (of Russia)—may God, glorified and exalted be He, assist him!—exerted his utmost endeavor to compass My deliverance. Several times permission for My release was granted. Some of the ‘ulamás of the city, however, would prevent it. Finally, My freedom was gained through the solicitude and the endeavor of His Excellency the Minister. …His Imperial Majesty, the Most Great Emperor—may God, exalted and glorified be He, assist him!—extended to Me for the sake of God his protection—a protection which has excited the envy and enmity of the foolish ones of the earth." The text of the letter from Bahá'u'lláh to the Shah carried by [[Badí‘]] was sent to Russian scholars by Russian diplomats and a catalog of works made its way to [[E.G. Browne]] awakening his interests. A few scholars in St. Petersburg reviewed Babí activities including the arrest and banishment of a Bábí to [[Smolensk]]. While the Bahá'í Faith spread across the [[Russian Empire]] in the late 1800s and early 1900s, and attracted the attention of scholars and artists, the Bahá'í community in Ashgabat built the first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]], elected one of the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly|local administrative institutions]] and was a center of scholarship. Early 1900s Russian Orthodox missionaries shared warnings against the religion, asserting that it violated 'the feelings of loyalty towards the Russian White Czar'{{cite book| last =Kolarz | first = Walter | authorlink =Walter Kolarz | title =Religion in the Soviet Union |publisher =St. Martin's Press | series =Armenian Research Center collection | year = 1962 | pages = 470–473 {{Subscription required|via=[[Questia]]}}|url =https://www.questia.com/read/419296/religion-in-the-soviet-union| isbn = }} and the law of the land made it illegal for Russians to convert from Christianity to another religion. There are several references to translations being undertaken of works into Russian in 1927{{cite magazine | title = Publishing Committee Report |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1927 |pages=9–10| url = | issue = 17}} as well as correspondence with Bahá'ís in Moscow and Ashgabat.{{cite magazine | title = Foreign Assembly Letters |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1927 | page =6| url = | issue = 19}} ==== Eastern Europe ==== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in Azerbaijan|Bahá'í Faith in Poland|Bahá'í Faith in Ukraine|Bahá'í Faith in Finland}} A group of Bábís formed in [[Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic|Nakhchivan]] and spread before 1850{{Citation|last=Balci |first=Bayram |last2=Jafarov |first2=Azer |title=The Baha’is of the Caucasus: From Russian Tolerance to Soviet Repression {2/3} |newspaper=Caucaz.com |pages= |date=2007-02-21 |url=http://www.caucaz.com/home_eng/breve_contenu.php?id=300 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524000119/http://www.caucaz.com/home_eng/breve_contenu.php?id=300 |archivedate=May 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} largely of Persian expatriates who were fleeing persecution in Persia. This group was attacked by the Russian army, under the command of General [[Vasili Bebutov]]. From 1850 on, small communities established themselves in elsewhere in Azerbaijan. Soon the community of Baku counted the largest number of believers in the region and in 1860 obtained official recognition from the authorities. The community recognized the newly announced position of Bahá'u'lláh. Soon there was more public awareness and some favor from leaders of the broader community and at the same time the Bahá'í community of Baku broadened its communication with other Bahá'í communities in [[Russia]], [[Bahá'í Faith in Turkey|Turkey]] and [[Bahá'í Faith in Turkmenistan|Ashkhabad]] and did much work printing materials in [[Turkish language|Turkish]].{{Cite journal| last = Walbridge|first = John | title = Chapter Four - The Baha’i Faith in Turkey | journal = Occasional Papers in Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Studies | volume = 06 |issue = 01 | date = March 2002 | url = http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/bhpapers/vol6/waless/chap4.htm | doi = | id =| postscript = .}} The most publicly recognized member of the community approaching 1900 was [[Musa Nagiyev]], one of Azerbaijan's richest citizens of the times though there were many public figures before and after who seem to have admired the religion or even been members of it. Similarly there were developments in to the north of Russian control. In Finland, contact began between traveling Scandinavians with early Persian believers of the religion led to published accounts in 1869, and the first mentions of Bahá'u'lláh were made in 1896{{cite web| author = National Spiritual Assembly of Norway| title = Skandinavisk bahá'í historie| work = Official website of the Bahá'ís of Norway| publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of Norway| date = August 2007| url = http://www.bahai.no/index.php?id=52&type=98| accessdate = 27 April 2008| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090909025901/http://www.bahai.no/index.php?id=52&type=98| archive-date = 2009-09-09| dead-url = yes| df = }} while Finland was politically part of the [[Russian Empire]]. In and during the [[Third Partition of Poland]] The first may have been in the 1870s when Polish writer [[:pl:Aleksander Walerian JabłonowskiAleksander|Walerian Jablonowski]]{{cite web | title = History in Poland | work = Official Webpage of the Bahá'ís of Poland | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Poland | year = 2008 | url = http://www.bahai.org.pl/?page_id=5 | accessdate = 2009-03-20 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090124040759/http://www.bahai.org.pl/?page_id=5 | archive-date = 2009-01-24 | dead-url = yes | df = }} wrote several articles covering its early history in Persia.{{Cite news|last=Jasion |first=Jan T. |title=The Polish Response to Soviet Anti-Bahá'í Polemics |periodical=Associate |publisher=Association for Bahá'í Studies (English-Speaking Europe) |volume=Winter 1999 |issue=29 |year=1999 |url=http://www.breacais.demon.co.uk/abs/associate/a29/page4.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215202703/http://www.breacais.demon.co.uk/abs/associate/a29/page4.htm |archivedate=2012-02-15 |df= }} This interaction was succeeded by writer [[Isabella Grinevskaya]] who joined the religion as well as interest by Leo Tolstoy (see below.) ==== Central Asia ==== {{main|Bahá'í Faith in Turkmenistan|Bahá'í Faith in Uzbekistan}} The Bahá'í Faith in Turkmenistan begins before [[Russia]]n advances into the region when the area was under the influence of [[Persia]]. By 1887 a community of Bahá'í refugees from [[religious violence]] in Persia had made something of a village in [[Ashgabat]]. Several years later — by 1894 — Russia made [[Turkmenistan]] part of the [[Russian Empire]]. Initially Russian diplomats observed the community as distinct from the Moslem one but being “closely knit community of honest, law-abiding people, somewhat reminiscent of the early Christian churches in the first century after Christ.” During that narrow period of time between 1887 and 1894, a court case was held following the assassination of a Bahá'í that for a time would vindicate the Bahá'ís. The Bahá'ís were represented by [[Mirza Abu'l-Fadl|Mirza Abu'l-Fadl Gulpaygani]] along with [[Shaykh Muhammad-'Alí]], each an [[Apostles of Bahá'u'lláh|Apostle of Bahá'u'lláh]], individuals who played a vital role in the development in the early stages of the religion comparable to the apostles of Jesus. Gulpaygani lived in Ashgabat off and on from 1889 to 1894. A short time after moving there, the assassination of one of the Bahá'ís there, [[Haji Muhammad Rida Isfahani]] occurred and Gulpaygani helped the Bahá'í community to respond to this event and later he was the spokesman for the Bahá'ís at the trial of the assassins was initiated by Czar [[Alexander III of Russia|Alexander III]] through a military commission from St. Petersburg.{{cite magazine | title = City of Love, by Bruce Whitemore|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1975 |pages=6–12| url = | issue = 52.7}} This event established the independence of the Bahá'í Faith from [[Islam]] both for the Russian government and for the people of Ashgabat. Under the protection and freedom given by the Russian authorities, the number of Bahá'ís in the community rose to 4,000 (1,000 children) by 1918 and for the first time anywhere in the world a true Bahá'í community was established, with its own hospitals, schools, workshops, newspapers, and a cemetery. This first [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] was constructed inside the city of Ashgabat. The design of the building was started in 1902, and the construction was completed in 1908 and was supervised by [[Vakílu'd-Dawlih]],{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= Encyclopædia Iranica |year= 1989|article=Bahai temples | first = V. | last = Rafati |author2=Sahba, F.}} The city's general population was between 44 and 50 thousand at this time.{{Cite book| last = Momen | first = Moojan| authorlink = Moojan Momen|author2=ed. Shirin Akiner| title = Cultural Change and Continuity in Central Asia, Chapter - The Bahá'í Community of Ashkhabad; it's social basis and importance in Bahá'í History| publisher = Kegan Paul International| year = 1991| location = London| pages = 278–305. | url = http://www.northill.demon.co.uk/relstud/ishqabad.htm| isbn = 0-7103-0351-3}} Within the lifetime of Bahá'u'lláh, the religion was established in [[Samarkand]], Uzbekistan, then under [[History of Uzbekistan (1876–1991)#Russian conquest|Russian control]]. While in Samarkand in 1892 Gulpaygani wrote a book, ''Fassl-ul-Khitab'' (Conclusive Proof), in response to the questions of Mirza Haydar-Ali of Tabriz.{{Cite journal | last = ibn-Kalanter | first = Ish'te'a'l | title = Mirza Abdul-Fazl | journal = Star of the West | volume = 14 | issue = 19| pages = 318–9 | publisher = | location = | date = March 2, 1914 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rw4YAAAAYAAJ&lpg=RA9-PA318&ots=FXCOyKPeYI&pg=RA9-PA318#v=onepage&q=&f=false | accessdate = 2010-02-19}} It was in Samarkand, too, that he debated a Protestant preacher. In 1910 the Samarkand Bahá'í community elected its first assembly in addition to having a school, and built a center which held four meetings a week. In [[Tashkand]], a community of Bahá'ís had expanded to about 1900 members, supporting a library, Persian and Russian language schools, and large meetings were being advertised with the permission of government authorities. Bahá'í literature published in Tashkand included several works of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], the next head of the religion. After the death of Gulpaygani, his papers, including several unfinished works, were taken to Ashqabat, where his nephew lived; many of these papers were, however, lost after the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]]. === Russian intellectuals === [[File:Isabella Grinevskaya.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Isabella Grinevskaya]].]] About nine Russian intellectuals or artists investigated the religion to varying degrees. Among the more well known and closest to the religion are [[Alexander Tumansky]], [[Isabella Grinevskaya]], and [[Leo Tolstoy]]. [[Lidia Zamenhof]] also was active towards the end of the period and into the Soviet era. Among the lesser known but more substantive in gathering original materials and from an earlier dates from the 1860s would be Jean-Albert Bernard Dorn and Nicolai Vladimirovich Khanykov both from St. Petersburg. Together their work was collected and published in Russian by Viktor Rosen and another book beginning to include works written by Bahá'u'lláh was done by [[Alexander Kasimovich Kazembek]]. An early translation of the [[Kitab-i-Aqdas]] into Russian was done by orientalist Alexander Tumansky published in about 1899. He befriended the Bahá'ís in Ashgabat during the trial where Gulpaygani wrote a treatise for him on the ''Risáliy-i Iskandaríyyh'' as a summary of the life of the founder.{{cite book | last =Mírzá Gulpáygání | first =Abu'l-Faḍl | authorlink =Mírzá Abu'l-Fadl| others=Juan Ricardo Cole (trans.)|title =Letters and Essays, 1886-1913 | publisher =Kalimat Press | year =1985 | pages =xii | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=fumT1mWfzDsC&lpg=PA43&pg=PR12#v=onepage&q&f=false | isbn = 9780933770362}} Later Tumansky was a professor of Arabic language at [[Tiflis]]. Isabella Grinevskaya was the pen name of a very early Russian Bahá'í born in [[Grodno]].{{cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=A.S.Fridberg , 6 Nov. 1838 - 21 March 1902 |work= |publisher= |url=http://holocaust.cheeb.com/photo6.html |doi= |accessdate=2009-03-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081215123824/http://holocaust.cheeb.com/photo6.html |archivedate=15 December 2008 }} Grodno was sometimes part of Poland and Belarus but during her entire lifetime was part of Russia.{{cite web | title = Short Description/History | work = Eastern BorderLands of the II Polish Republic | publisher = Paul Havers | date = 2008-11-18 | url =http://www.kresy.co.uk/grodno.html | doi = | accessdate = 2009-03-22}} She is well known because of a play she wrote called ''Báb''{{cite web| last = Grinevskaya | first = Isabella | title = Bab | work = | publisher = | year = 1916|edition=reprint| url = http://imwerden.de/pdf/grinevskaya_bab.pdf |format = pdf | doi = | accessdate = 2009-03-21}} which was performed in St. Petersburg in 1904 and again in 1916/7, translated into French and [[Tatar language|Tatar]], and later wrote a play ''Bahá'u'lláh'' though it was never staged. Leo Tolstoy corresponded on the Bábí and Bahá'í Faiths from 1894 until shortly before his death in 1910.[http://www.bahai-studies.ca/journal/files/jbs/3.3%20Collins&Jasion.pdf Lev Tolstoi and the Bábí and Bahá’í Faiths A Bibliography] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505095519/http://www.bahai-studies.ca/journal/files/jbs/3.3%20Collins%26Jasion.pdf |date=2012-05-05 }} by William P. Collins and Jan T. Jasion, Journal of Bahá’í Studies Vol. 3, number 3 (1991) His correspondents, who also sent him translations of Bahá'í writings, include Bahá’ís such as {{Interlanguage link multi|Hippolyte Dreyfus|fr|3=Hippolyte Dreyfus-Barney}}, Isabella Grinevskaya, Dr. Yúnis Khán-i-Afrúkhtih, and ‘Ali-Akbar Nakhjavání (father of [[Ali Nakhjavani|Alí-Yulláh Nakhjavání]].) In the fall of 1902 Mirza 'Azizu'llah visited Tolstoy with a personal message from `Abdu'l-Bahá and discussed the history and teachings of the religion during a period of house arrest that followed his excommunication from the Orthodox church. Elsewhere `Abdu'l-Bahá suggests that Tolstoy was a well-wisher of humanity but that he was still caught up in politics and opinion. Luigi Stendardo’s thesis “Tolstoj et la Foi Bahá’íe” (later revised and published in English as "Leo Tolstoy and the Bahá’í Faith") provides an excellent analysis of Tolstoy’s changing views on the religion. Tolstoy ended life feeling that he could possibly subscribe to the religion but at the same time had major reservations with regard to the Bahá’í doctrine of the [[Manifestation of God]], which insists that God is knowable only through his Manifestations, that these Manifestations are in essence different from and above other humans and that they are infallible. In sum Tolsoy, despite his inability to accept some Bahá’í doctrines, was able to declare that “the teachings of the Bábís which come to us out of Islam have through Bahá’u’lláh’s teachings been gradually developed and now present us with the highest and purest form of religious teaching”. Lidia Zamenhof, the youngest daughter of [[L. L. Zamenhof|Ludwig Zamenhof]], was born in 1904 in [[Warsaw]], then in the [[Russian Empire]]. She was an active promoter of Esperanto and around 1925 she became a member of the religion.{{cite encyclopedia |last= Smith |first= Peter|encyclopedia= A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title= Zamenhof, Lidia |year= 2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location= Oxford |isbn=1-85168-184-1 |page=368}} Through her efforts and a Russian translation of "Bahá'u'lláh and the New Era" the first Ukrainian joined the religion in 1939.{{cite magazine | title = First Ukrainian Bahá'í |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1946 | page =8| url = | issue = 183}} === Period of the [[Soviet Union]] === Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development| format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-10-16}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 |year = 1997 |url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development }} and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}} Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. World-wide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socioeconomic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. However, only in the brief period before the 1930s in the [[Soviet Union]] were Bahá'ís able to provide services based on their teachings. After that Soviet member states adopted the [[Religion in the Soviet Union#Policy toward religions in practice|Soviet policy of oppression of religion]], so the Bahá'ís, strictly adhering to their principle of obedience to legal government, abandoned its administration and properties.{{cite book | last = Effendi | first = Shoghi | authorlink = Shoghi Effendi | title = The World Order of Bahá'u'lláh |publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust, 1991 first pocket-size edition | date = 1936-03-11 | location = Haifa, Palestine | pages = 64–67 | url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/WOB/wob-34.html#pg64| isbn = }} For example, in 1924 Bahá'ís in Turkistan had schools and a special committee for the advancement of women.{{cite magazine | title = Foreign Bahá'í News |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July–August 1925 | page =7| url = | issue = 6}} All such developments were dissolved in the face of advances of policies on religion in the Soviet era. In 1922 early Bahá'í [[Wellesley Tudor Pole]] began a long association with a project aimed at relieving the oppression the [[Bolsheviks]] imposed on religionists in Russia.{{cite web | last = Fenge | first = Gerry | title = Wellesley Tudor Pole.com | work = A few highlights from a full life (timeline) | publisher = Wellesley Tudor Pole.com | url =http://wellesleytudorpole.com/page2.htm | accessdate = 2008-11-08}} [[`Alí-Akbar Furútan]], born 1905, moved with his family to Ashgabat in what was then Russian Turkestan and, through his years of school and university, he took an active part in the work of the Bahá'í communities of Ashgabat, Baku, Moscow, and other parts of Russia. He attended secondary school in Ashgabat and later graduated from [[Moscow University]] with a degree in psychology and child education.{{cite magazine | title = Visit of Hand of the Cause Mr. Furútan to North America |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1970 | page =3| url = | issue = 466}} In 1930 he was expelled from the Soviet Union during the Stalinist persecution of religion, and, from that time on, played an ever more significant role in the work and administration of the Iranian Bahá'í community.[http://news.bahai.org/story/261 High-ranking member of the Baha'i Faith passes away] 26 November 2003 Other tales of arrests and forced deportations are noted as early as March.{{cite magazine |title = Circular Letter from Assembly of Haifa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1930 | page =7| url = | issue = 8}} Nevertheless, the head of the religion personally covered the costs of translating the [[Hidden Words]] into Russian in 1933.{{cite magazine | title = Closing of Geneva International Bureau Recalls Devoted Efforts of Secretary |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1957 | page =4| url = | issue = 320}} Rules against the religion began in 1922 of a general nature. Then in 1926 Bahá'ís in Moscow were detained, printed materials confiscated and some homes seized. Communist anit-Bahá'í pamphlets had been produced and encyclopedic articles were published in 1930 and 1933 partially reacting to the success of the religion reaching those who rejected by Islam and Communism. Queen consort [[Marie of Romania]] had received a brooch from her royal relatives in Russia in previous decades. Circa 1926 she joined the religion and gave this brooch to [[Martha Root]] who in turn sent it as a gift to the first Bahá'í House of Worship of the West where it was sold to raise money for the contraction to a Willard Hatch. In 1931 he took it with him when he went on [[Bahá'í pilgrimage]] where with approval of [[Shoghi Effendi]] it was placed in the archives of the religion.{{cite magazine | title = Queen Marie of Rumania Renowned First Royal Believer, by O. Z. Whitehead |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1973 | pages = 2–6| url = | issue = 504}} In 1938 "monstrous accusations" accusing Bahá'ís of being 'closely linked with the leaders of [[Trotskyite]]-[[Basmachi movement|Bukharinist]] and [[Dashnak]]-[[Musavat]] bands'. Following this numerous arrests and oppression of the religion, Bahá'ís across the Soviet Union were being sent to prisons and camps or sent abroad. Bahá'í communities in 38 cities across Soviet territories ceased to exist. In Tashkent Bahá'ís were interrogated and imprisoned. Aqa Habibullah Baqiroff of Tashkent was sentenced to ten years imprisonment "in the neighbourhood of the North Sea and the polar forests." Many were sent to [[Pavlodar]] in northern Kazakhstan. (See [[Bahá'í Faith in Kazakhstan]].) By 1946 in all Turkestan only Ashgabat, Samarkand and Tashkand communities continued. Bahá'ís had managed to re-enter various countries of the [[Eastern Bloc]] through the 1950s, following a plan of the head of the religion at the time, [[Shoghi Effendi]]. But by 1956 there is a vague mention of an operating community of Bahá'ís in Uzbekistan.{{cite magazine | title = The Guardian's Message to the forty-eighth annual Baha'i Convention |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1956 | number = 303 |pages=1–2 | url =}} In 1955 a delegation of Russian journalists to America were forbidden to visit the North American Bahá'í House of Worship.{{cite magazine | title = Baha'i in the News |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1955 | page =10| url = | issue = 295}} The 1957 letter of the head of the religion challenged Bahá'ís to find a way to have one Bahá'í in each Soviet Republic on the European continent: Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, White Russia, Moldavia and Ukraine.{{cite magazine | title =A Thrice Blessed World Crusade|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1957 | page =2| url = | issue = 316}} In 1962 in "Religion in the Soviet Union", [[Walter Kolarz]] notes:
"Islam…is attacked by the communists because it is 'reactionary', encourages nationalist narrowmindness and obstructs the education and emancipation of women. Baha'iism(sic) has incurred communist displeasure for exactly the opposite reasons. It is dangerous to Communism because of its broadmindness, its tolerance, its international outlook, the attention it pays to women's education and its insistence on equality of the sexes. All this contradicts the communist thesis about the backwardness of all religions."
A pair of small communities are listed in 1963 - [[Tashkand]] and an isolated Bahá'í in [[Fergana]].[http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#22 The Bahá'í Faith: 1844-1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953-1963], Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land, page 95. The [[Universal House of Justice]], the head of the religion since 1963, then recognized small Bahá'í presence across the USSR of about 200 Bahá'ís. In 1973 two aides and their wives from the Russian delegation to Panama went on a brief tour of the House of Worship built there.{{cite magazine |title =The Panama Temple Today|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1973 | page =17| url = | issue = 507}} There are reports of sporadic arrests and interviews in Ashgabat by the [[KGB]] as late as 1982. However, in November 1987 the second Secretary in the Russian Embassy to India escorted the USSR's Ambassador-at-Large to the Bahá'í [[Lotus Temple]] and later a group of 120 performing artists from the [[Bolshoi Theatre]] of Russia visited it too.{{cite magazine |title =Temple has banner month in November|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1988 | page =12| url = | issue = 682| issn = 0195-9212}} And the Bahá'í Publishing Trust of Germany was able to have a booth at the sixth International Book Fair in Moscow.{{cite magazine |title =This book display by Baha'i Verlag… (Photo caption)|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1988 | page =17| url = | issue = 682| issn = 0195-9212}} Russian diplomats in India as well as ballet dancers again visited the Indian House of Worship in 1988{{cite magazine |title =Temple has banner month in November |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1989 |pages=4–5| url = | issue = 695| issn = 0195-9212}} and 1989 this time including Orthodox Church leaders, film personalities, poets and intellectuals.{{cite magazine |title =Temple has another busy month|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1989 |page =2| url = | issue = 695| issn = 0195-9212}} Also in 1989 twenty-six Bahá'ís from Finland took part in a "Peace and Environmental Festival" in [[Murmansk]].{{cite magazine |title =Temple has another busy month|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1989 |page =13| url = | issue = 704| issn = 0195-9212}} == Re-development == As [[Perestroyka]] approached, the Bahá'ís began to organize and get in contact with each other. Before the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union]] Bahá'ís in several cities were able to gather and organize. The Bahá'í community of Ashgabat was the first to re-form its Local Spiritual Assembly approximately in 1987 and had doubled its numbers from 1989 to 1991 and had successfully registered with the city government of Ashgabat. From 1988 the Bahá'ís in [[Moscow]] and then in Baku became active (see also [[Bahá'í Faith in Ukraine]].) Bahá'ís in Azerbaijan sought recognition from the State Department of Religion of Azerbaijan. By the end of 1990, after 50 almost years, the election for the Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Baku was held followed by other communities before 1992. In this brief time [[`Alí-Akbar Furútan]] was able to return in 1990 as the guest of honor at the election of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the Soviet Union. Continuing the popularity of the Indian Bahá'í House of Worship, individuals from multiple cities of Russia and former Soviet republics, as well as groups of researchers, reporters, and their families went in winter 1989 and spring 1990.{{cite magazine |title = India|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1990 |page =15| url = | issue = 704| issn = 0195-9212}} However, as the nations established themselves they began drawing up laws regulating religions to the point all the Bahá'í communities were de-established. In 1995 in Turkmenistan, 500 adult religious adherent citizens were required in each locality in order for a religious community to be registered. Thus by 1997 the Bahá'ís were unregistered by the government along with several other religious communities,{{Cite news| author-link = Amnesty International| title = TURKMENISTAN - Harassment and imprisonment of religious believers| work =| publisher = Amnesty International| date = 2000-03-01| url = http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/3b83b7047.html| accessdate = 2010-11-10}} and more than just being unable to form administrative institutions, own properties like temples, and publish literature, perform scholarly work and community service projects -their membership in a religion is simply unrecognized, the religion is considered banned,{{Cite news| last = Corley| first = Felix| author-link = Felix Corley| title = TURKMENISTAN: Religious freedom survey, April 2004| newspaper = F18News| date = 2004-04-07| url =http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=296| postscript = }} and homes are raided for Bahá'í literature.{{Cite news| last = Corley| first = Felix| author-link = Felix Corley| title = TURKMENISTAN: Religious communities theoretically permitted, but attacked in practice?| newspaper = F18News| date = 2004-04-01| url = http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=293| postscript = }} As of 2007, under these harsh conditions, the Bahá'í community in Turkmenistan has still been unable to reach the required number of adult believers to be recognized by the government as a religion.{{Cite web| author = U.S. State Department| title = Turkmenistan -International Religious Freedom Report 2007| publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair| date = 2007-09-14| url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90236.htm| accessdate = 2008-05-21}} In 1992 the Parliament of Azerbaijan adopted the law of religious liberty and Bahá'ís gained an opportunity to officially register communities and the National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Azerbaijan was elected, effectively disbanded since 1938. In 1993 the Governing Board of the Ministry of Justice of the Azerbaijan Republic gave official permission for the functioning of the Bahá'í Community of Baku. The Bahá'ís of Baku are seeking the return of property confiscated during the Soviet era—especially a house that served as the Bahá'í Center.{{cite web| author = U.S. State Department| title =International Religious Freedom Report 2006- Azerbaijan| publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair| date = 2006-09-15| url = https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71368.htm| accessdate = 2008-12-22}}{{Cite news| last = Corley | first = Felix | title = AZERBAIJAN: Baha'is and Baptists want confiscated property back | newspaper = F18News | date = 2005-11-23 | url =http://www.forum18.org/Archive.php?article_id=694}} In the case of Russia proper the situation was similar. From 1990 to 1997 Bahá'ís had operated in some freedom, growing to 20 groups of Bahá'ís registered with the federal government, but the [[Law on Freedom of Conscience and Religious Associations]] passed in 1997 is generally seen as unfriendly to minority religions though it hasn't frozen further registrations.{{cite web | last =Dunlop | first =John B. | authorlink =John B. Dunlop | title =Russia’s 1997 Law Renews Religious Persecution | publisher = Demokratizatsiya | year = 1998 | url =http://www.gwu.edu/~ieresgwu/assets/docs/demokratizatsiya%20archive/07-01_dunlop.pdf | format = pdf | accessdate = 2012-09-21}} == Modern community == Because of the quick pace of the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union]] simultaneously with the religious freedoms initially achieved, local, regional and national assemblies formed and evolved in parallel. The first [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of Moscow was elected in 1990 followed by a summer [[Bahá'í school]] attended by some 60 Bahá'ís from across the region and followed by a public concert.{{cite magazine |title =Soviet Union |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1990 |page =15| url = | issue = 711| issn = 0195-9212}} The National Spiritual Assembly (NSA) of the USSR was elected in 1991 which in 1992 became the NSA of Russia, Georgia & Armenia, and then in 1995 became NSA of the [[Russian Federation]], while over the same period various Soviet republics formed their own NSAs from 1992 through 1994. In the late summer of 1992, members of the Marion Jack Teaching Project who were working mostly within Russia at the time, came to Mongolia to participate in a concerted effort to share the religion with a wider range of Mongolians.{{Cite web | title = Bahá'í leads Ealing Studios in 21st Century | work = UK Bahá'í Review | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United Kingdom | url =http://www.bahai.org.uk/uk_review/prev_iss/7/p13.htm| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080310075244/http://www.bahai.org.uk/uk_review/prev_iss/7/p13.htm|archivedate = May 2008| accessdate = 2010-06-12}} [[Ulaanbaatar]] was the gathering place for more than 1,800 Bahá'ís from Mongolia and Russia in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://news.bahai.org/story/690|title=World’s coldest capital hosts Baha’i conference|publisher=news.bahai.org}} After Liudmila St. Onge (Luda) was interested in the religion while in America she mentioned she was on her way to Russia. She was encouraged to seek out the Baha'is in Moscow and in Russia officially joined the religion. Luda’s trip to Russia lasted much longer than anticipated, as she decided to introduce her new business of scrapbooking to Russia. This has proven very successful. She returned to New Hampshire in July 2010, and informed the local Baha'is that she had joined the religion and was eager return.[http://184.73.195.130/Luda Why Baha'i: Liudmila St. Onge (Luda)] November 4, 2010 [[Firuz Kazemzadeh]] is a noted scholar on Russian history, born in Moscow, and an active Bahá'í in the United States. He has published several works on Russian history.* {{cite book | last =Kazemzadeh | first = Firuz | authorlink =Firuz Kazemzadeh | title =Russia and Britain in Persia, 1864-1914: A Study in Imperialism | publisher =Yale University Press | series =Yale Russian and East European studies | volume =Volume 6 | year = 1968 |language = | url = | isbn = }} * {{cite book | last =Kazemzadeh | first = Firuz | authorlink =Firuz Kazemzadeh | title=The struggle for Transcaucasia, 1917-1921|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K9xWAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=|year=1981|publisher=Hyperion Press|isbn=978-0-8305-0076-5}} * {{cite book | last =Kazemzadeh | first = Firuz | authorlink =Firuz Kazemzadeh | editor-last = Avery| editor-first =P. | editor2-last = Hambly|editor2-first = G. R. G. | editor3-last = Melville| editor3-first= C. | title = From Nadir Shah to the Islamic Republic| edition= illustrated, reprint, reissue |series =The Cambridge History of Iran | volume = 7| publisher =Cambridge University Press | chapter =Iranian relations with Russia and the Soviet Union, to 1921| chapterurl = | year = 1991| origyear = | pages = 314–349 | url = | isbn = 9780521200950 }} The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated about 18,990 Bahá'ís in 2005. === Persian accusations associated with community in Russia === {{main|Political accusations against the Baha'i Faith}} Both Soviet and Iranian governments produced trumped up charges against the religion as an excuse to pursue a violent oppression of the religion. In the case of the Soviets in 1938 "monstrous accusations" accusing Bahá'ís of being 'closely linked with the leaders of [[Trotskyite]]-[[Basmachi movement|Bukharinist]] and [[Dashnak]]-[[Musavat]] bands'. Following this numerous arrests and oppression of the religion, Bahá'ís across the Soviet Union were being sent to prisons and camps or sent abroad. Bahá'í communities in 38 cities across Soviet territories ceased to exist. In the case of modern Iran it used the history of conflict between Iran and Russia as a circumstance to find Bahá'ís blameworthy. During the 19th century [[Russia]] had been expanding south and east into Central Asia toward India where Britain held power at the time. A rivalry started between Britain and Russia over territorial and political control in Central Asia followed. The middle zone of land was where both Russia and Britain worked to gain influence.{{citation |last=Amanat |first=Abbas |year=1989 |title=Resurrection and renewal: The making of the Bábí movement in Iran, 1844-1850 |location=Ithaca, NY|publisher=Cornell University Press |isbn=0-8014-2098-9|pages=23–28}} Struggles in the region lead to Persian antagonism to both foreign powers.{{cite web | first = Ahmad | last = Ashraf | url =http://www.iranian.com/May96/Opinion/Conspiracy.html | title = Conspiracy theories and the Persian Mind | accessdate = 2008-07-13 | year = 1997 |publisher = Iranian.com}} Muslim clerics and other anti-Bahá'í groups connected the Bahá'í Faith, and its predecessor the Bábí movement, to the external governments of Britain and Russia to project the mistrust of these two latter groups onto the Bahá'ís.{{citation |chapter = Anatomy of Prejudice | title = The Baha'is of Iran: Socio-historical studies | last = Chehabi | first = H.E. | editor-last = Brookshaw |editor-first = Dominic P. |editor2-last = Fazel | editor2-first = Seena B. | year = 2008 | publisher = Routledge | location = New York, NY |isbn = 0-203-00280-6|pages = 186–188}} In addition to government and clergy-led [[Persecution of Bahá'ís|persecution of the Bahá'ís]], [[Iran]]ian government officials and others have claimed that [[Political accusations against the Baha'i Faith|Bahá'ís have had ties to foreign powers]], and were agents of Russian imperialism and more.{{citation | title = Human Rights, the UN and the Bahá'ís in Iran | first = Nazila | last = Ghanea | publisher = [[File:KilmoreCathederal.jpg|thumb|200px|The [[St Fethlimidh's Cathedral, Kilmore|Cathedral Church of Saint Fethlimidh, Kilmore]], the episcopal seat of the [[Church of Ireland]] bishops. Within the grounds lies the pre-Reformation Cathedral, now used as a [[parochial hall]].]] [[File:Cavan Cathedral.JPG|thumb|200px|The [[Cavan Cathedral|Cathedral of Saints Patrick and Felim]], [[Cavan Town]], the episcopal seat of the Post-Reformation Roman Catholic bishops.]]
The '''Bishop of Kilmore''' is an [[Episcopal polity|episcopal]] title which takes its name after the parish of [[Kilmore, County Cavan]] in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. In the [[Roman Catholic Church]] it remains a separate title, but in the [[Church of Ireland]] it has been united with other bishoprics.
==History== The [[Episcopal see|see]] of Kilmore was originally known as Breifne ([[Latin]]: ''Tirbrunensis'', ''Tybruinensis'' or ''Triburnia''; [[Irish language|Irish]]: ''Tír mBriúin'', meaning "the land of the descendants of [[Brión mac Echach Muigmedóin|Brian]]", one of the [[List of kings of Connacht|kings of Connaught]]) and took its name after the [[Kingdom of Breifne]].<ref name=handbook362>{{Harvnb|Fryde|Greenway|Porter|Roy|1986}}, ''Handbook of British Chronology'', p. 362.</ref><ref name=rckilmoredio>{{cite web |url=http://www.kilmorediocese.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=13&Itemid=35 |title=Diocese: Statistics and Brief History |work=Diocese of Kilmore |publisher= |accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Ireland900.png|200px|thumb|left|The overkingdoms of Ireland circa 900, including the [[Kingdom of Breifne]] which has approximately the same boundaries with the diocese of Kilmore.]]
The see became one of the dioceses approved by Cardinal [[Giovanni Paparoni]] at the [[synod of Kells]] in 1152,<ref name=handbook362/> and has approximately the same boundaries as those of the ancient [[Kingdom of Breifne]].<ref name=rckilmoredio/> In the [[Irish annals]], the bishops were recorded of ''Breifne'', ''Breifni'', ''Breifny'', ''Tir-Briuin'', or ''Ui-Briuin-Breifne''.
In the second half of the 12th century, it is likely the sees of Breifne and [[Kells, County Meath|Kells]] were ruled together under one bishop.<ref name=handbook357>{{Harvnb|Fryde|Greenway|Porter|Roy|1986}}, ''Handbook of British Chronology'', p. 357.</ref> In 1172, Tuathal Ua Connachtaig took the [[oath]] of [[fealty]] to King [[Henry II of England]] as bishop of Kells.<ref name=handbook363>{{Harvnb|Fryde|Greenway|Porter|Roy|1986}}, ''Handbook of British Chronology'', p. 363.</ref> Soon after 1211 the see of Kells was incorporated into the [[diocese of Meath]].<ref name=handbook357/>
In 1454, [[Pope Nicholas V]] gave permission for the then bishop, Aindrias Mac Brádaigh ([[Anglicisation|Anglicised]]: Andrew McBrady), to have the ancient church at [[Kilmore, County Cavan|Kilmore]], founded in the 6th century by [[Saint Felim]] (or Feithlimidh), to be the [[cathedral church]] of the diocese.<ref name=rckilmoredio/> This building passed into the hands of the [[Church of Ireland]] at the [[Reformation in Ireland|Reformation]], and, following the construction of a [[St Fethlimidh's Cathedral, Kilmore|new cathedral]], is now used as a [[parochial hall]].<ref name=kilmorecathedral>[http://www.travelmania-ireland.com/place.php?id=21 St. Feithlimidh's Cathedral, Kilmore] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304023323/http://www.travelmania-ireland.com/place.php?id=21 |date=4 March 2016 }}. ''Travelmania''. Retrieved on 29 May 2011.</ref>
After the upheavals of the Reformation, there were parallel [[apostolic succession]]s: one of the Church of Ireland and the other of the [[Roman Catholic Church]].
In the Church of Ireland, the title was intermittently held with [[Bishop of Ardagh|Ardagh]] until they were finally united in 1839. In 1841, the [[Bishop of Kilmore and Ardagh|sees of Kilmore and Ardagh]] were amalgamated with [[Bishop of Elphin|Elphin]] to form the united [[Bishop of Kilmore, Elphin and Ardagh|bishopric of Kilmore, Elphin and Ardagh]]. The current incumbent is The Right Reverend Samuel Ferran Glenfield M.A. M.Th. (Oxon.) M.Litt. He was elected, consecrated, and installed in 2013.
In the Roman Catholic, the title continues as a separate bishopric. The current [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|Bishop]] of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Kilmore]] is the Most Reverend '''[[Philip Leo O'Reilly]]''', who succeeded as the [[diocesan bishop]] on 16 October and installed at the [[Cavan Cathedral|Cathedral Church of Saints Patrick and Felim, Cavan]] on 15 November 1998. He had been appointed [[coadjutor bishop]] of Kilmore by the [[Holy See]] on 20 November 1996 and received [[Consecration|episcopal ordination]] on 2 February 1997.

==Bishops during the Reformation== During the Reformation, Edmund Nugent and John MacBrady were at one time or another bishops of either the Church of Ireland or Roman Catholic succession. They were each appointed as Roman Catholic bishops, but later accepted or recognized as [[Anglicanism|Anglican]] bishops.<ref name=handbookpp398and436/>

==Notes== <div style="font-size: 95%"> * {{note label|Note1|A|A}} These two are possibly the same individual. * {{note label|Note1|B|B}} Cormac Mág Shamhradháin and Tomás Mac Brádaigh were rival bishops, and probably supported by rival [[Sept (social)#Irish septs|septs]] within the diocese. They were present at [[Ecclesiastical province|provincial]] councils held by Ottaviano Spinelli de Palatio, [[Archbishop of Armagh (Roman Catholic)|Archbishop of Armagh]], in 1492 and 1495, and were both then recognized as bishops of Kilmore. But Diarmaid Ó Raghillaigh was appointed to the see in 1512 before Cormac's death, though Cormac was still maintaining his rights at that date. </div>
